Michigan Ongoing Health & Safety Training Refresher 2023
Section 3: Prevention & Control of Infectious Disease (Including Immunizations)

Covid-19 Pandemic

We all have been affected by the Covid-19 Pandemic, also known as the Coronavirus Pandemic. Check the Center for Disease Control for updated recommendations. 

  • Ongoing pandemic, first identified in December 2019 in China

    A Pandemic is a contagious disease that is prevalent over an entire country or the entire world. The Covid-19 Pandemic was first identified in December of 2019 in Wuhan, China. It quickly spread throughout the world.

  • Symptoms may occur 2 to 14 days after exposure, most experience symptoms 2 to 7 days after exposure

    Occasionally someone could be a carrier of the disease and not have any symptoms. Normally symptoms occur 2 to 14 days after exposure with an infected individual. Most experience symptoms within 2 to 7 days of exposure.

  • Human to Human transmission via respiratory droplets

    The mode of transmission is human to human transmission via respiratory droplets. This means it travels through the air especially when the infected person coughs or sneezes.

  • Symptoms

    Symptoms include, but are not limited to: A cough (usually dry), Shortness of breath or difficulty breathing, Fever (usually over 101 F), Chills, Sore Throat, Muscle Pain, Tiredness, and Loss of Taste or Smell.

    The severity and duration of symptoms can vary significantly. Death can be the result of severe respiratory distress and occasionally blood clots.

  • Prevention Measures

    The following prevention measures have been recommended by the Center for Disease Control and several medical experts. 1) Wearing a mask that fits snugly over the mouth and nose; 2) Social Distancing which involves avoiding mass gatherings and maintaining a distance of 6 feet from others; 3) Good hand hygiene; and 4) Covid Immunizations and Boosters.
